Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Phylogeographic discord in the comparative genomic history of Amazonian birds
Award.AbstractNarration:
The production of species diversity is of fundamental interest, but the factors that cause diversification are poorly understood. Diversification is known to occur at different rates depending on the species or group of species involved, and comparative study of this variation can reveal the processes that promote diversity. Comparative phylogeography is the study of diversification at the population level within different species, and it allows us to observe differences in diversification at the point where speciation occurs. The goals of this study are to use comparative phylogeography and novel methods of generating data to detect differences in diversification across species, and to analyze the factors that promote faster diversification in some species than in others. Phylogeography will be compared across sixteen Amazonian bird species with similar distributions. A new set of genetic markers scattered across the genome will be used to generate data from 24 individuals of each species. These genetic sequences will be extracted from museum tissue samples using a new method of enriching genomic DNA for sequences of interest, and then sequenced on a next-generation sequencing instrument. New analytical tools for testing models will allow us to measure the processes that are most important in driving the diversification of a given species. The massive amount of data generated by this method will allow for analysis of more complex models than could ever be analyzed previously, giving us new insight into the processes promoting species diversity.

This project provides research opportunities for undergraduate students in Louisiana and the geographic scope of the project fosters inter-institutional and international collaborations. The research provides a test of next-generation sequencing methods and a new genomic marker set, and our results will aid in the application of these methods to other study systems. New biogeographic and geographic genetic data from our work support conservation efforts in the Amazon. All specimens, audio recordings, and observational data from our fieldwork and genetic data from our lab work are deposited in publicly accessible collection and databases. We consider these resources invaluable for current and future, pure and applied research on Amazonian birds and other systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Michael Harvey, under the supervision of Robb Brumfield, has completed the project "Phylogeographic discord in the comparative genomic history of Amazonian birds" supported by an NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant. This project expanded on the ideas addressed in the previous three projects of his dissertation, which was accepted by the LSU Graduate School in fulfillment of his PhD requirements this past November (2015). During the funding period, Michael worked primarily in the lab to obtain DNA sequence data from existing samples in museum collection for studying the phylogeographic histories of Amazonian birds, but he also completed an expedition to Peru to gather additional samples.

Harvey, in conjunction with collaborators and undergraduate research assistants, accomplished the goal of his research, to complete a large-scale comparative phylogeographic study of 40 bird species. Phylogeography is the field involved in estimating the histories of populations of organisms through time and across space using genetic data, and it draws heavily from methods used in the related fields of population genetics and phylogenetics. Harvey's project, however, was unprecedented in terms of the size of the dataset examined. The final dataset involved 464 samples from across the Amazon Basin. Moreover, new genomic techniques allowed him to obtain genetic data from across the genome, which resulted in data from 2,417 unique genomic regions. Assembling this dataset required him to develop a new bioinformatics pipeline (available online at http://github.com/mgharvey/seqcap_pop) to obtain usable data from reads off of an Illumina DNA sequencer. 

All of this data allowed Harvey to estimate levels and patterns of genetic diversity as well as population history in each study species with greater accuracy and precision. The ultimate goal, however, was to compare these estimates across species in order to determine what might be causing species to have different levels of diversity or population histories. Comparative methods including generalized linear mixed models and phylogenetic generalized least squares revealed that the habitat a bird occupied was an important predictor of its genetic diversity and population history. Birds that live in upland forest have greater genetic diversity, more population genetic structure, and older population histories than species that live in forest in the extensive river floodplains of the Amazon. He also noted that species in the forest understory had higher diversity and deeper histories than those inhabiting the canopy. 

This project is one of the first to show that the ecology of a species, in the form of which habitat it uses, predicts its genetic diversity and evolutionary history. This is significant because it suggests that ecology and be used as an indicator of genetic characteristics of a species that are important for conservation and management. Also, the link between ecology and evolution demonstrated in this study suggests that the ecology of a species might have a deterministic effect on its evolutionary trajectory, implicating ecology differences among species as a driver of differences in diversity among different organismal groups. This is a largely unproven and exciting idea in evolutionary ecology.

The results of Harvey's study are publicly available in his dissertation (available from http://etd.lsu.edu/cgi-bin/ETD-browse/browse). He is also finalizing a primary manuscript based on these findings for submission to a peer-reviewed journal, and anticipates several secondary publications based wholly or partly on these data. Harvey has recently started a postdoctoral position at the University of Michigan, which continues to investigate similar themes to those explored in this project.
